If one sees that there are sentient beings to be liberated by oneself, it is because of the attachment to self.
Why not want the attachment to self and so forth?
The sÅ«tra says: The TathÄgata says that the attachment to self is not attachment.
What is the meaning of not?
It means not good.
Why is it not good?
Because it binds sentient beings and makes them dwell in birth and death.
Moreover, not means having no essence.
What does this mean?
Because there is nothing to be grasped, there is also no one who can grasp.
If the attachment to self and so forth cannot be obtained as having an essence, why use the words not attachment to negate the self?

It is because ordinary beings mistakenly grasp due to delusion. In order to make them understand, it is said that attachment is not attachment, as the sÅ«tra says only the ignorant and deluded give rise to false grasping.

Those who have not yet attained the holy [realizations] each grasp at their own self, giving rise to distinctions, called the birth of ordinary beings. That is not birth, because it is an inauspicious birth, like an inauspicious person being called a non-person.
Moreover, because dharmas arise from conditions and are not created by a self, they are called non-birth.
Therefore, it is said to be the birth of ordinary beings, because it accords with conventional speech.
Because sentient beings often give rise to attachment to the Buddha's physical body, therefore it is further said that the physical body has no nature.
The sÅ«tra says: SubhÅ«ti!
What do you think?
Can one see the TathÄgata by perfecting his physical characteristics?
Up to a wheel-turning sage king would then be the TathÄgata. It is like this.
The Buddha wishes to make the meaning of the Dharma body in the view of the physical body, etc., easy to uphold, and therefore speaks a verse:
If one sees me in form, or seeks me in sound,
This person practices the wrong path and cannot see the TathÄgata.
The TathÄgata's body is the Dharma, one should only contemplate the nature of dharmas;
The nature of dharmas is not something seen, they also cannot know it.
To see me with form and so forth, what is the meaning of this?
It means that there are those who see the light and excellent characteristics, saying they see the Buddha;
And there are those who listen to and accept the sÅ«tras and other texts, saying they follow and attain the TathÄgata.
They say that by taking the body of excellent characteristics and the body of speech as objects of meditation, one will be able to eliminate afflictions.
In order to eliminate this view, the sÅ«tra says, This person walks the wrong path and cannot see the TathÄgata.
What is the meaning of this?
Form and words are not real by nature, to grasp onto them is the wrong path, how can one who walks this path see the Buddha?
How should one see?
The sÅ«tra says, The TathÄgata's body is the Dharma, one should only contemplate the nature of dharmas.
The nature of dharmas refers to emptiness, no self-nature, no arising nature, and so forth, which is precisely the ultimate body of the buddhas.
If one sees this, it is called seeing the Buddha.
As a sÅ«tra says, Non-arising and non-ceasing is the TathÄgata.
The one hundred thousand verse sÅ«tra also says, Maitreya, seeing emptiness is called seeing the TathÄgata.
The Satyakaparivarta SÅ«tra also says, Seeing without grasping is called seeing the Buddha.
If seeing without grasping is called seeing the Buddha, is not taking the nature of dharmas as an object grasping?
With a pure wisdom mind, one understands the nature of dharmas. Could the nature of dharmas be what is understood?
Therefore, a sÅ«tra says, The nature of dharmas is not seen, and they also cannot be known.
Where there is the nature of dharmas, there is not a single thing that can be called what is known, and therefore that wisdom also cannot know it.
As a sÅ«tra says, Great King!
The nature of all dharmas is like empty space, equally serving as the support for many things, yet its essence is neither existent nor nonexistent.
Being able to be silent and unknowing in this is called true knowledge.
It is called knowledge because it is spoken in accordance with worldly convention.
Furthermore, doubt arises:
If even wisdom cannot know the nature of dharmas, how do the Buddhas, who are fully endowed with the characteristics of a great man, realize bodhi?
Because it is seen that one who is fully endowed with the characteristics of a great man attains bodhi.
In order to dispel this doubt, the sÅ«tra says, SubhÅ«ti!
What do you think?
Did the TathÄgata, by perfecting the characteristics, attain supreme, perfect enlightenment? and so forth. Herein, the characteristics of the Dharma realm are revealed.
What is the meaning of this?
If the characteristics are truly existent, then when these characteristics cease, it would be called annihilation.
There is no bodhisattva who sees the annihilation of dharmas.
Why is this?
Because of arising, there is then cessation.
All dharmas are of the nature of non-arising, and therefore they are far removed from the two extremes of permanence and annihilation.

Being far removed from the two extremes is the characteristic of the dharma realm, and therefore it is said that the merit of being able to believe and understand non-arising is greater than the merit of giving jewels.
As the sÅ«tra says, SubhÅ«ti!
If good men and good women were to use the seven treasures of worlds as numerous as the sands in the Ganges River to give to others;
if bodhisattvas attain the acceptance of dharmas as non-arising and non-self, and so forth, it is only because the merit of joyfully cultivating non-arising is greater than that.
As a verse says:
If a person upholds the true Dharma and gives rise to the mind of enlightenment,
It is not as good as understanding emptiness, even a sixteenth of it.
Or one might think:
If all dharmas are non-arising, how can there be the arising of merit?
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says, SubhÅ«ti!
Bodhisattvas should not grasp at merit and so forth.
One should not grasp at merit means that in the ultimate truth there is no merit to be grasped.
SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If bodhisattvas do not grasp at merit, it is because bodhisattvas should perfect merit.
The Buddha said:
SubhÅ«ti!
Bodhisattvas should grasp at it because of conventional truth;
They should not be attached to it because of ultimate truth.
Moreover, there is doubt:

If in the ultimate truth there is no merit to be grasped, why did other sÅ«tras say The TathÄgata's accumulation of merit and wisdom is perfected, sitting on the seat of enlightenment, heading for nirvÄá¹‡a?
In order to dispel this doubt, the sÅ«tra says SubhÅ«ti!
If there is someone who says:
The TathÄgata either goes or comes, either stands or sits, or lies down.
This person does not understand the meaning of what I have said.
NirvÄá¹‡a has no real place to which one can arrive, and that is called going;
Birth and death also have no true location, and to come from there is called coming.
Not going and not coming is the meaning of Tathagata, which is the manifestation of the nirvana of no abiding.
Although birth and death and nirvana are not one or different, yet within the prison of the three realms, one uses analogies for sentient beings, benefiting them until the end of the future.
Next, there is doubt:
If because birth and death and nirvana cannot be attained there is no going and coming, is the Tathagata then like Mount Sumeru, accumulated and abiding together?
In order to eliminate the views of oneness, permanence, no parts, and having parts, the sutra says, Subhuti!
If good men and good women were to shatter the trichiliocosm into tiny motes of dust, would those motes of dust be many? and so forth.
Here, many motes of dust eliminates the view of no parts and having parts.
Not a collection of subtle particles eliminates the view of indivisible wholes.
This is called a collection of subtle particles means that divisible objects are referred to as a collection.
In order to further eliminate the view of accumulation, the sutra says The Thus-Come One says the three thousand great one-thousand worlds are not really worlds and so forth.
Why does it again say not really worlds?
The sutra says If the worlds really existed, it would be a view of indivisibility.
Why does it not want a view of indivisibility?
The sutra says It would not be a view.
What is not a view?
Because it falsely sees what does not exist.
As the sutra says Indivisibility is precisely the inexpressible, but I see that ordinary beings grasp at its phenomena.
What is the meaning of this?
Indivisibility is the characteristic of conventional truth, not truly existent.
Why is this?
In the ultimate truth, the inherent nature of all dharmas is originally unborn. Since they are unborn, they cannot be obtained. Since they cannot be obtained, they are beyond verbal expression.
Yet ordinary beings who grasp at selfhood falsely take [hold of them].
If one does not wish to contradict the teachings of the view of selfhood, there is a verse that goes like this:
I rely on myself, how can I rely on others?
The wise one who can tame the self, will be reborn in the heavens and experience bliss.
To dispel this doubt, the sutra says, Subhuti!
If there is someone who says:
The Tathagata speaks of the view of self, the view of sentient beings, the view of life, and the view of grasping.
Is this correct speech? and so forth.
Why did the Buddha speak of the view of self?
It is in order to guide and attract those who have faith and delight in it. This is a conventional name and expression in accordance with the five aggregates, not the true reality.
Therefore, the self that is seen by the buddhas is a nature of detachment, as the sutra says it is not the view of self and so forth.

The World-Honored One, having already separated from birth and death and nirvana, has attained enlightenment by combining the two. He further has compassion for all sentient beings and wishes to enable them to attain the same realization. Therefore, he says, SubhÅ«ti!

Those who give rise to the vehicle of the bodhisattvas should know all dharmas in this way, see in this way, and have faith and understanding in this way, and should not give rise to the notion of dharmas.
Knowing and seeing refers to the time of realization.
Faith and understanding refers to the time of cultivation and learning.
For one who has faith and understanding, the notion of dharmas does not arise, let alone the notion of non-dharmas.
As for the notion of dharmas and the notion of non-dharmas, it means the notion of dharmas that arises from proper discrimination and the notion of dharmas that arises from improper discrimination.
Why does the proper notion of dharmas not arise?
The sutra says, The TathÄgata says that the notion of dharmas is not a notion.
What does this mean?
It is because all dharmas are by nature unborn.
If they are unborn, then they do not exist. What is there to know and see?
It is because of conventional truth, as stated in the sutra, This is called the notion of dharmas.
Why is the merit of upholding it also mentioned?
It is to make sentient beings ultimately have faith.
The sÅ«tra says: Not speaking is called speaking.
What does this mean?
In the ultimate truth, there is no worldly or transcendent, no dharma or entity, that can be spoken of.
One who can speak in accordance with the true meaning is called a speaker.
This unconditioned nirvÄá¹‡a is realized only after observing conditioned phenomena.
How does one observe?
The sÅ«tra says: At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
All conditioned phenomena are like stars, cataracts, lamps, and illusions,
Dew, bubbles, dreams, lightning, and clouds - one should observe them in this way.
In this verse, the conditioned phenomena are observed in nine aspects.
What are the nine?

Namely, observing self-mastery, observing objects, observing change, observing essence, observing little prosperity, observing life, observing action, observing mind, observing existence and non-existence.

Among them, observing self-mastery is like stars. It is like stars and such, attached to the elephant in the sky, running in the directions, with radiant colors, even if lasting for a long time, will eventually follow the end of the kalpa.

In this way, humans and gods receive various blessings and rewards, with abundant wealth and high status, looked up to by the masses. Even if lasting for a long time, self-mastery will eventually return to emptiness.

Observing objects is like cataracts. It is like a person with cataracts seeing hair, floating hairs, double moons, and such in the clear sky. The consciousness obscured by ignorance is also like this. In the place of true reality, where there are no objects, it sees various mundane and supramundane dharmas.

Observing impermanence as like a lamp, it is like a lamp flame that arises and ceases in the very place it arises, not reaching other places, yet because of this flame, flames arise in other places, with a continuity of moments as if there were impermanence;

sentient beings are also like this, the aggregates that go to the previous destinies cease in the very place they go, not going to other destinies, yet because of the previous aggregates, the aggregates of the subsequent destinies arise, and because of the continuity, it appears as if there is impermanence, saying that ordinary beings frequently go to other destinies.

Observing the essence as like an illusion, it is like an illusory woman created by the power of an illusion, with an appearance that can be seen but an essence that does not exist, those who do not understand take her to be real;
all dharmas are also like this, arising from false conditions, originally without a real essence, those who do not understand reality give rise to the view that they have a real essence.
Observing youth and vigor as like dew, it is like morning dew that disappears when it meets the sun;
youthful appearance is also like this, once it encounters impermanence, it immediately withers and fades away.
Contemplating life as like a bubble, like a water bubble, some are just born and have not yet formed a body, some are just born, some temporarily stay and then return to scattering and disappearing;
Life is also like this, either just conceived and in the womb, just born, born and then becoming a baby, youth, middle-aged, and then old, returning to destruction.

Contemplating the doer as like a dream, like in a dream, following what was previously seen and heard, due to the power of memory and discrimination, although there is no doer, various objects clearly appear;

In the same way, sentient beings, from beginningless time, have afflictions and wholesome and unwholesome karma that remain due to habituation, although there is no self that is the doer, yet the affairs of birth and death, etc., are clearly present.
Contemplating the mind as like lightning, like lightning, when it appears it immediately disappears;
The mind is also like this, in a moment it must pass away.
Contemplating existence and non-existence as like clouds, like clouds in the sky, first non-existent, then existent, and in a moment again disappear;
Conditioned dharmas are also like this. Their essence is originally empty, existing due to false conditions. When the conditions disperse, they return to non-existence.

Furthermore, first relying on conventional truth, using the nine analogies such as stars, establishes conditioned dharmas. Later, relying on the first truth of the Middle Treatise, all dharmas are neither extinguished nor produced, neither cut off nor permanent, neither one nor different, neither coming nor going out, and in Prajnaparamita, all dharmas are not the nature of accumulation and abiding, to explain this verse.
What is the meaning?
It is like the light of stars, whose essence is always extinguished. Conditioned dharmas are also like this, their nature always changing and passing away.
It is like a person's blurred vision. Although there is no creator, it arises due to the conditions of illness. Conditioned dharmas are also like this, only arising from conditions.
It is like the flame of a lamp, always extinguished moment by moment. Conditioned dharmas are also like this, not abiding for a moment.

It is like what is created by an illusion. One who does not understand takes it to be real and permanent. The deluded person is confused about reality and grasps at conditioned dharmas, also like this.

It is like dew on objects, although abundant in form it is only one thing, namely moisture. The internal aggregates of conditioned existence are born and born with differences, but their fundamental nature is the same, all benefiting from love.

Like water accumulating to form bubbles, each is born separately and each perishes separately. The activities of sentient beings are also like this, with eighty-four thousand separate births and deaths.

Like objects in a dream that come from nowhere, yet the dreaming mind falsely sees a place they come from. Conditioned existence is also like this, coming cannot be attained, the ignorant dreaming consciousness falsely sees it as coming.

Like a rushing lightning bolt, its nature is not moving and changing. In the previous place it perishes, in the later place it is born. Because the characteristics are similar, it is said to be going. The characteristics of conditioned dharmas going are also like this.
Like empty clouds that do not always accumulate and abide, the characteristics of conditioned existence should be understood as being like this.
This is called establishing conditioned existence based on the conventional truth.
As the Madhyamaka ÅšÄstra establishes the meaning of non-arising of true reality, one should understand conditioned dharmas in this way.
How is this so?

In that treatise, self, other, common, and causeless are used to investigate the meaning of the inherent non-arising of dharmas. One should understand that arising conditioned dharmas that resemble cataracts are non-arising.
Because of non-arising, the extinction of the light of stars contradicts reason. Conditioned [dharmas] are also like this and should be understood as non-extinguishing.
Furthermore, because of non-arising, the self-nature of that lamp cannot even be obtained. How could there be a moment that is said to be severed?
Conditioned [dharmas] that are not severed should be understood in this way.
Furthermore, because of non-arising, conditioned dharmas that resemble magical creations have no meaning of permanence. One should understand that they are not permanent.
Furthermore, because of non-arising, conditioned dharmas resemble morning dew. One meaning is not established.
Because attachment cannot moisten arising, it does not accord with reason. One should understand that they are not one.
Furthermore, because of non-arising, it is similar to a bubble in distinguishing differences. The nature of conditioned dharmas is not established as different, and should be known as non-different.
Furthermore, because of non-arising, it is similar to objects in a dream. The nature of conditioned dharmas originally has no meaning of coming, and should be known as not coming.

Furthermore, because of non-arising, it is similar to a flash of lightning. The dharma of arising and ceasing is said to be a goer because of similarity, but the principle is not compatible, and should be known as not going.
Furthermore, because of non-arising, the substance of the dharma is still non-existent, let alone accumulated and abiding?
In this way, it should be known.
